Posts.Content: IceStationZebra: My high PSA reading in December was most likely a residual effect of the biopsy of a couple months before agitating my prostate. When things settled down, my PSA went down to my "normal" level.
Posts.Signature: * Age: 49 * PSA: - 1/14/17: 3.3 - 8/12/17: 4.3 - 12/13/17: 5.2 - 3/13/18: 6.0 - 9/14/18: 7.4 * Biopsy: - 10/8/18: 2/12 cores positive, both cores 3+3, both cores 10% involvement, both cores NPI * Oncotype DX: - 12/13/18: Unable to report due to insufficient RNA quality or quantity * PSA: - 12/15/18: 12.9 - 1/14/19: 7.8
Posts.Title: Second Pathology Opinion

Posts.Content: After my diagnosis in October, I met with a surgical oncologist for a second opinion regarding treatment options. He confirmed that I would be a good candidate for active surveillance. I am wondering whether in my case (only 2 cores, 3+3 and 10% involvement each) it is advisable also to have my pathology slides reviewed by a second pathologist? What do people generally do? Thanks!

AgeInfo.Phrase: whether in my case  only 2 cores  3 3 and 10%

Posts.Signature: * Age: 49 * PSA: - 1/14/17: 3.3 - 8/12/17: 4.3 - 12/13/17: 5.2 - 3/13/18: 6.0 - 9/14/18: 7.4 * Biopsy: - 10/8/18: 2/12 cores positive, both cores 3+3, both cores 10% involvement, both cores NPI * Oncotype DX: - 12/13/18: Unable to report due to insufficient RNA quality or quantity * PSA: - 12/15/18: 12.9 - 1/14/19: 7.8
Posts.Title: Second Pathology Opinion

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply, MF. My next biopsy is scheduled for October later this year, 1 year after my first one. I discussed my relatively high PSA level vs. low volume cancer situation with the oncologist, and he wasn't very concerned about the biopsy possible having missed a bigger/worse lesion.
Posts.Signature: * Age: 49 * PSA: - 1/14/17: 3.3 - 8/12/17: 4.3 - 12/13/17: 5.2 - 3/13/18: 6.0 - 9/14/18: 7.4 * Biopsy: - 10/8/18: 2/12 cores positive, both cores 3+3, both cores 10% involvement, both cores NPI * Oncotype DX: - 12/13/18: Unable to report due to insufficient RNA quality or quantity * PSA: - 12/15/18: 12.9 - 1/14/19: 7.8
Posts.Title: Second Pathology Opinion

Posts.Content: Hello forum, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer last October. In the biopsy, 2 of 12 cores were positive. The highest Gleason score was 3 + 3. Overall prostatic tissue involvement was 1.7%. The stage is T1c. Now the month before the biopsy, my PSA was 7.4. But in December, my PSA went up to 12.9. What could this mean? Does this mean that it is very likely that the biopsy in October missed a larger/more serious lesion? I have been reading along on this forum for a while now, but this is my first post. Thank you for being such a helpful resource!
Posts.Title: Low grade, high PSA

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your helpful replies. Here is some more information about my background & history (I'll try to get this into my signature): - Age: 49 - PSA 1/14/17: 3.3 - PSA 8/12/17: 4.3 - PSA 12/13/17: 5.2 - PSA 3/13/18: 6.0 - PSA 9/14/18: 7.4 - Bx 10/8/18: 2/12 cores positive, both cores 3+3, both cores 10% involvement, both cores NPI - PSA 12/15/18: 12.9 All my DREs so far have been negative. Based on the high reading of my latest PSA test and the general upward trend over time before December, my urologist thinks that most likely my prostate cancer is more advanced than detected in the biopsy. My next PSA test is scheduled for 1/15/19 (to rule out infection or other irritation of the prostate). If the next PSA result is also high, he strongly suggests I should undergo a prostatectomy, after an MRI etc. for staging.

AgeInfo.Phrase: this into my signature     Age  49   PSA 1 14 17  3

Posts.Title: Low grade, high PSA

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your informative and hopeful responses. I am happy to report that my PSA score went down to 7.8, which is just 0.4 higher than before my biopsy. My next PSA test is scheduled for mid-April. I also have an appointment early March for a second opinion regarding next treatment (or not) steps in the current situation. MF, I was not advised to have a biopsy back in 2017. Given my "low" (under 10) PSA score, my urologist didn't suggest an MRI at this point when I saw him last month.
